questions.text: A 54-year-old man who is a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension experiences severe, sudden-onset chest pain radiating to the left arm and profuse sweating. He was admitted to the emergency ward. An ECG is taken which is as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding blood lactate dehydrogenase levels in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sudden onset chest pain with profuse sweating and 12 Lead Electrocardiogram (ECG) with ST-segment elevation in Leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of myocardial Infarction. Serum LDH 1 > LDH 2 levels are seen in this condition. 

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. So, normally LDH 2 > LDH 1 in blood. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream. This results in a flipped lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) ratio where LDH 1 > LDH 2.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH-2 HHHM RBC and kidneys
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text:
A mother who had given birth to a female child flees with her husband late at night, leaving the baby behind at the hospital. This act is punishable under which section of the IPC?

IPC: Indian penal code
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts an act with the intention of abandoning a child who is under the age of 12 years, which is a punishable offense under Section 317 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Section 317 of the IPC states that if the father or mother or anyone having the care of a child under the age of twelve years, leaves the child in any place with the intention of abandoning the child, they shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years even more so for a term. The punishment may extend to ten years if the child so exposed or abandoned is a girl child. They may also be asked to pay a fine of up to 1 lakh rupees.

In India, infanticide is considered murder, and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Option C: IPC 316 – Causing the death of a quick unborn child (fetus whose movements can be felt) by any act amounts to culpable homicide. Punishment can be up to ten years imprisonment. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 2 lakh rupees.

Option D: IPC 315 – This section covers a person doing an act intended to prevent the child from being born alive or to cause it to die after its birth. They are punished with imprisonment for up to 7 years. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 1 lakh rupees.

Option A: Section 318 IPC – It deals with concealment of birth.

questions.text: In a research study, a total of 200 mCi of Deuterium Oxide (D2O) is injected into the venous blood of a volunteer. During a 2 hour equilibration period, he excretes 25% of the injected deuterium oxide. If plasma concentration of D2O is subsequently measured to be 0.333mCi/100 ml, calculate the total body water in this volunteer.
questions.solution:
The Total Body Water (TBW) in this volunteer would be 45L.

The volume of each of the body fluid compartments can be measured by the dilution method. By this method, the volume of the TBW in this patient is calculated by the formula:

Where,
  • V = TBW volume in liters (L)
  • Amount of deuterium oxide (marker) injected = 200 mCi
  • Amount of deuterium oxide excreted = 25% of 200 mCi = 50 mCi
  • Plasma concentration of deuterium oxide = 0.333 mCi/100mL = 3.33 mCi/L 

By substituting the given values, the volume of total body water is calculated as:

TBW Volume = (200 - 50)/3.3

                   = 45 liters

Therefore, the total body water in this volunteer would be 45 litres.

Isotopic water like deuterium oxide (D2O) would be distributed everywhere that water is found in the body due on account of its lipid solubility. Therefore, it can be used as an appropriate marker substance for the calculation of total body water. Other markers for total body water include tritiated water (THO) and antipyrine.

Estimation of total body water is of clinical importance due to its direct correlation with important parameters like a person's body weight. Water accounts for about 50-70% of the total body weight and in the absence of other comorbidities, the magnitude of weight loss is directly proportional to the amount of total body water that is lost.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man, who is a known case of diabetic nephropathy, undergoes renal transplant from an HLA-matched donor. The transplant is successful and he is kept on immunosuppressive therapy. On follow-up visits, there is a steady rise in serum creatinine levels over a period of four months. A tissue biopsy is taken and the histopathological examination is as given below. What type of graft rejection is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing a patient presenting with progressive renal failure manifested by a rise in serum creatinine over a period of 4 months along with histopathology showing inflammatory cells within the capillary loops, accumulation of mesangial matrix, and duplication of the capillary basement membrane is characteristic of transplant glomerulopathy which is a chronic antibody-mediated rejection.

Chronic rejections start clinically manifesting 4-6 months after transplantation with the main features being proteinuria and hypertension. This is the rationale behind serum creatinine monitoring after a kidney transplant. Acute rejection on the other hand occurs within days or weeks after transplantation and is the principal cause of early graft failure. It occurs much later if immunosuppression is tapered or stopped which is not the case in the given clinical scenario. Absolute differentiation between acute and chronic rejection is based on histological features which are as shown in the image above, portraying a case of transplant glomerulopathy. 

On the basis of the morphology and the underlying mechanism, rejection reactions are classified as hyperacute, acute, and chronic.

Hyperacute rejection:

  • Occurs within minutes or hours after transplantation.
  • Immunoglobulin and complement are deposited in the vessel wall, causing endothelial injury and fibrin-platelet thrombi.
  • Neutrophils rapidly accumulate within arterioles, glomeruli, and peritubular capillaries.
  • The kidney cortex then undergoes outright necrosis (infarction). Hence the transplant appears pale, almost "white".

Acute transplant rejection is due to cellular or humoral rejection of the graft after the transplant is done. It takes time to develop and may be seen within a few days in untreated recipients or years later when immunosuppression is tapered. Either cellular or humoral mechanism predominates. It can be overcome by adequate immunosuppressive therapy.

The immunochemical staining of the biopsy specimen may show both CD4 (helper) and CD8 (cytotoxic) lymphocyte infiltration.

Acute cellular rejection:

  • Acute cellular rejection also called an acute T cell-mediated rejection, is most commonly seen within the initial months after transplantation and is heralded by clinical and biochemical signs of organ failure.
  • It was thought that direct killing of graft cells by CD8+ CTLs is a major component of the reaction.
  • They have two histological patterns :
    • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial inflammation and tubular inflammation (tubulitis) associated with focal tubular injury
    • Vascular pattern: It shows either inflammation of vessels (type II) or necrosis of vessel walls (type III)

Acute antibody-mediated rejection:

  • Acute antibody-mediated rejection is caused by anti-donor antibodies produced after transplantation.
  • It is manifested mainly by damage to glomeruli and small blood vessels. Typically, there is inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries

Chronic antibody-mediated rejection:

Chronic antibody-mediated rejection usually develops insidiously, without preceding acute rejection, and primarily affects vascular components. Antibodies are detected in the circulation.

Chronically rejecting kidney grafts show glomerulopathy, with duplication of the basement membrane, likely secondary to chronic endothelial injury and peritubular capillaritis with multilayering of peritubular capillary basement membranes. Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma may occur secondary to the vascular lesions.

Cell-mediated reactions play a very small role in chronic rejections and so chronic rejections are considered to be antibody-mediated rejections.

Related Pearl: Classification of Transplant Rejection Reactions

Hyperacute rejection (minutes to hours):

  • Mechanism: Antidonor antibodies present in the circulation of the recipient
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Grossly, cyanotic and mottled graft with pale white areas
    • Neutrophils accumulate
    • Acute fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls or complete occlusion by thrombi

Acute rejection (days to weeks):

  1. Acute cellular rejection (acute T cell-mediated rejection):  
    • Mechanism: CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage graft.
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
      • Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III): Endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
  2. Acute antibody-mediated (humoral) rejection: 
    • Mechanism: antibodies bind to endothelium and activate complement causing damage and graft failure
    • Histopathological findings:
      • Inflammation of glomeruli and peritubular capillaries.
      • Activation of the antibody-dependent classical complement pathway.
      • Focal thrombosis in small vessels. 

Chronic rejection (months to years):

  • Mechanism: T-cells react against alloantigens and secrete cytokines which stimulate fibroblasts and vascular smooth muscle cells (graft arteriosclerosis). Chronic rejection may also be antibody-mediated.
  • Histopathological findings:
    • Predominantly vascular changes (intimal thickening and vascular occlusion)
    • Glomerulopathy with duplication of basement membrane
    • Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy with loss of renal parenchyma

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who underwent a coronary artery bypass 6 days ago developed fever and productive cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. His chest X-ray and sputum culture on Cetrimide agar are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed Late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia (> 5 days). The chest-Xray shows wedge-shaped opacity involving the right middle lobe, suggestive of bacterial pneumonia. Culture shows the growth of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in Cetrimide agar with colonies showing  greenish-yellow fluorescein pigment.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown).

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles
  • Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

  • Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila
  • Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Other options:

  • Klebsiella species has no particular selective medium and is usually differentiated through biochemical reactions
  • Staphylococcus aureus is selectively cultured in Mannitol salt agar, Ludlam's medium and Salt milk agar. Mannitol salt agar showing golden-yellow S. aureus colonies is given below.

Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia and grows selectively on BCYE (Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) medium. It is as shown below.

questions.text: A patient who is a known asthmatic on low-dose inhalational corticosteroids comes to the OPD with complaints of acute exacerbations. On this visit, theophylline is added to his treatment regimen and shows better symptom control. He returns after a few days with complaints of nausea, headache, gastric discomfort, and excessive micturition. Which of his side effects is not due to phosphodiesterase-4  inhibition?
questions.solution:
The diuretic effect of theophylline is due to the blockade of adenosine (A1) receptors. All the other symptoms are caused by the inhibition of PDE4.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that acts by:

  • Inhibition of phosphodiesterase enzyme (PDE). PDE3 inhibition causes relaxation of bronchial smooth muscle and PDE4 inhibition causes inhibition of the release of cytokines and chemokines which further leads to a decrease in immune cell migration and activation.
  • Blockade of adenosine receptors, which inhibits bronchoconstriction. However, blockade of A1 receptors in the glomerular afferent arteriole and PCT causes diuresis.
  • Activating enzyme histone deacetylase-2, which is responsible for its anti-inflammatory action

Adverse effects of theophylline are usually related to plasma concentration ( >15 mg/L). The most common side effects are headache, nausea, and vomiting, abdominal discomfort (due to inhibition of PDE4), and restlessness.

At high concentrations, cardiac arrhythmias may occur due to inhibition of cardiac PDE3 and antagonism of cardiac A1 receptors. At very high concentrations, seizures may occur due to central A1 receptor antagonism.

A targeted plasma concentration of 5-10mg/L is maintained to avoid adverse effects and drug interactions.

Related Pearl: Drugs which need Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM)

Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM).

The mnemonic "DATLAAT MC" can be used.

  • D: Digoxin
  • A: Anti-arrhythmic
  • T: Theophylline
  • L: Lithium
  • A: Aminoglycosides
  • A: Anti-epileptics
  • T: Tricyclic antidepressants
  • M: Methotrexate
  • C: Calcineurin inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following is the thickest region of the lens capsule?
questions.solution:
The lens capsule is thickest at the pre-equatorial region.

The lens capsule is a thick, collagenous basement membrane that is transparent and is thickest at the pre-equatorial region and thinnest at the posterior pole. The epithelium cells are of two types: those in the central zone that are not actively dividing and cells in the pre-equatorial germinative zone that give rise to the lens fibers. The lens epithelium secretes the lens capsule and regulates the transport of metabolites, nutrients, and electrolytes to the lens fibers.

Note: Parson's mentions that the thickest region of the capsule is the anterior pre-equatorial region while Myron Yanoff mentions that the thickest region of the capsule is the posterior pre-equatorial region of the capsule as shown in the image below.

questions.text:
A patient presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. A barium swallow was performed which showed the following image. Which of the following is most likely seen on high-resolution manometry?

DCI - Distal contractile Integral

IRP - Integrated relaxation pressure

choices.text: Normal Median IRP, premature contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm
Elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), premature contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture showing retrosternal chest pain and dysphagia with a barium swallow showing cork-screw appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) which is diagnosed with a normal median IRP and premature contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles.

Investigations :

A barium swallow shows corkscrew esophagus. 

However, manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis.

  • On classic manometry - simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) are suggestive of DES (as given in the question).
  • On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (Distal contractile Integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. This is in accordance with the latest Chicago classification.

Treatment: Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

The older terms "diffuse esophageal spasm" and "jackhammer (nutcracker ) esophagus" have been replaced in the Chicago classification by Distal esophageal spasm and Hypercontractile esophagus respectively.

Other options : 

Option A - Hypercontractile esophagus (jackhammer) is diagnosed with at least two swallows showing DCI >8000 mmHg-s-cm and hypercontractility localized to the LES on high-resolution manometry.

Option C - ≥50% fragmented contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm is seen in Fragmented peristalsis which is a minor disorder of motility

Option D - Type III Achalasia (spastic Achalasia) shows an elevated median IRP (>15 mmHg), no normal peristalsis and premature (spastic) contractions with DCI >450 mmHg-s-cm with ≥20% of swallows on high-resolution manometry. Barium swallow shows the following image in achalasia characterized by a bird beak sign.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is suspected to have Fragile X syndrome. He is sent to the psychiatric OPD for a referral. After a psychiatric evaluation, the consultant asks you, an intern, to assess the child's IQ. Which test is the most widely used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The most widely used test of intelligence for school-age children and adolescents is the third edition of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children

It is applicable for children from 6 to 17 years of age and yields a verbal IQ, a performance IQ, and a combined full-scale IQ.

Verbal subtest categories :

  • Vocabulary
  • Information
  • Arithmetic
  • Similarities
  • Comprehension
  • Digit span (supplemental)

Performance subtest categories :

  • Block design
  • Picture
  • Completion
  • Picture arrangement
  • Object assembly
  • Coding
  • Mazes (supplemental)
  • Symbol search (supplemental)

Scoring :

  • An average full-scale IQ is 100
  • 70 to 80 represents a borderline intellectual function
  • 80 to 90 is in the low average range
  • 90 to 109 is average
  • 110 to 119 is a high average
  • above 120 is in the superior or very superior range

Other options :

Option B - The Stanford-Binet Intelligence Scale (2 to 24 years) relies on pictures, drawings, and objects for very young children and on verbal performance for older children and adolescents. It gives a mental age score as well as an intelligence quotient.

Option A and C - The McCarthy Scales of Children's Abilities and the Kaufman Assessment Battery for Children are two other intelligence tests that are available for preschool and school-age children. They do not cover the adolescent age group.

  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age

  • Mullen scale - 0 months to 68 months

questions.text: While working out at the gymnasium, you witness a weightlifter collapse. What is the correct sequence to be followed to provide basic life support to this victim?

choices.text: Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, check for pulse, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, call the emergency response team,  assess responsiveness, check for pulse, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation(CPR)
Verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse , commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Verify scene safety, check for pulse,  assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)

questions.solution:
Basic life support should be provided in the following sequence for a witnessed collapse: verify scene safety, assess responsiveness, call the emergency response team, check for pulse, and then commence cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

First, assess scene safety to ensure the environment is safe for the rescuers and the victim.

The next step is to check for responsiveness. If unresponsive, activate the emergency response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED) before starting CPR if you are alone. Otherwise, send someone to activate the response system and get the automated external defibrillator (AED).

Check the patient for a carotid pulse for 5-10 seconds. If the patient has a pulse but no normal breathing or only gasping, provide 1 breath every 6 seconds or 10-12 rescue breaths /minute and recheck pulse every 2 minutes.

If the patient does not have a pulse and is not breathing, proceed to provide high-quality CPR.

Continuous chest compressions should be given on the lower 1/3rd of the patient's sternum by pushing hard and fast at the rate of 100-120/minute, at a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5-6 cm) allowing complete chest recoil after every compression. Rescue breaths are given every 6 seconds or 10-12 breaths/minute.

Effective chest compressions in a child older than 1 year and up to puberty should be at the compression rate is 100 - 120/min  (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec), depth of 2 inches by pressing hard and fast. Allow for full chest recoil after every compression. Minimize interruptions in chest compression to less than 10 seconds.

Analyze if it is a shockable rhythm when the AED arrives. If it is shockable, then give one shock and proceed with CPR. If it is a non-shockable rhythm then continue CPR immediately.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

Related Pearl: Neurocutaneous syndomes

Von Hippel Lindau Syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: VHL gene, tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Conditions associated with it include:
    • Renal cell carcinoma
    • Hemangioblastomas
    • Pheochromocytomas
    • Angiomatosis
    • Cysts in the pancreas, liver, and kidneys

Neurofibromatosis type 1: 

  • Also known as Von Recklinghausen Disease
  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF1 gene on chromosome 17, codes for the Neurofibromin protein
  • Features of NF 1:  “CAFE SPOTS”
    • Café-au-lait spots (multiple, >6, >5 mm in children or >15 mm in adults)
    • Axillary or inguinal freckling
    • Family history (autosomal dominant inheritance)
    • Eye findings (Lisch nodules on the iris)
    • Skin neurofibromas (benign tumors)
    • Plexiform neurofibromas (larger, deeper tumors)
    • Optic pathway gliomas (tumors of the optic nerve)
    • Tibial dysplasia (bone abnormalities, e.g., bowing of the tibia)
    • Skeletal abnormalities (e.g., scoliosis)

Neurofibromatosis type 2:

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Gene defect: NF2 gene on chromosome 22 that codes for the Merlin protein
  • Features: "MISME"
    • Multiple schwannomas (bilateral vestibular schwannomas are hallmark)
    • Intracranial meningiomas
    • Spinal tumors (ependymomas, schwannomas)
    • Meningiomas (intracranial or spinal)
    • Ependymomas (spinal cord tumors)

Tuberous sclerosis: 

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Mutation in the TSC 1 gene on chromosome 9 and TSC 2 on chromosome 16
  • Features: “HAMARTOMAS”
    • Hamartomas in skin and CNS
    • Ash-leaf spots (Hypopigmented macules)
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Angiofibromas (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Rhabdomyomas of the heart
    • Tuberous sclerosis
    • Autosomal dOMinant
    • Angiomyolipomas
    • Seizures and shagreen patches
    • Also associated with intellectual disability

Sturge Weber Syndrome

  • Also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis
  • Somatic mosaicism due to mutation in GNAQ gene
  • Features: “STURGE - I”
    • Portwine Stain (Nevus flammeus)
    • Tram track calcifications (leptomeningeal angioma)
    • Unilateral weakness
    • Retinal detachment and atrophy
    • Glaucoma
    • Epilepsy
    • Intellectual disability

questions.text: Fordyce's spots are known as glands of Tyson when present in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Fordyce spots located in the coronal sulcus of the penis to either side of the frenulum have been referred to as the glands of Tyson

Fordyce spots are sebaceous glands without hair follicles and these sebaceous glands are an example of holocrine gland.

Glands have been classified into 3 types, which includes:

Apocrine Holocrine Eccrine (Merocrine)
Apical part of cell sheds off during discharge Whole-cell disintegrates during discharge The cell is intact and secretions are thrown out by exocytosis
Eg: Apocrine sweat glands in axilla and groin, mammary glands, the external auditory canal (ceruminous glands) and eyelids (glands of Moll) Eg: Glands of Zeis and Meibomian gland, Montgomery tubercle: Nipple and areola, Tyson's gland: External fold of the prepuce, Fordyce' spot: Vermillion border of lips and mucosa Eg: Sweat glands on palms and solesFound everywhere except clitoris, glans penis, labia minora, external auditory canal and lips

Tyson glands are also known as pearly penile papules and are as shown below :

Related Pearl: Fordyce Spots

Fordyce spots/Fordyce granules:

  • The Fordyce spots are heterotopic sebaceous glands wherein the duct is connected directly to the overlying skin or mucosal surface unlike other sebum glands which open into the follicle.
  • They are called ectopic/free-lying sebaceous glands.
  • They occur commonly on the vermilion border of upper lip(m/c), buccal mucosa, skin over penile shaft and areolar of the breast.
  • They are commonly multiple and appear as symmetrical discrete yellow papules.
  • Fordyce spots on penis are called Tyson glands.
  • They are asymptomatic.
  • Treatment ladder
    • First line: Reassurance
    • Second line
      • Local destruction with superficial cautery or electrodessication
      • Topical trichloracetic acid 

Image: Fordyce spots on the vermilion border of both lips in A, upper lip in B, and buccal mucosa in  C.

questions.text: The patient presents with sudden onset of fever and painful burning lesions on his right knee. Which of the following is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
A systemic response(fever), along with prodromal symptoms like pain and presence of grouped herpetiform vesicles developing on the erythematous base is classical of Herpes zoster infection. In this case fluconazole is not indicated.

Tricyclic antidepressants are given for the management of pain.

Glucocorticoids are given for reduction of inflammation. However, it should not be used without concomitant antiviral therapy.

questions.text: On suddenly dropping an infant’s head in relation to her trunk, you notice the response seen in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding different components of this response?

choices.text: Hand opening is present by 28 weeks
Upper limb extension and abduction is present by 32 weeks
Anterior flexion with audible cry appears by 40 weeks

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Moro’s Reflex. In Moro's reflex, anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks.

 The different components of Moro's reflex appear as following:

  • Hand opening appears at 28 weeks.
  • Upper Limb extension and abduction appear at 32 weeks.
  • Anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks

Moro’s reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age.

An asymmetrical Moro's reflex is indicative of root plexus injury.

Moro’s is considered to be the only unlearned fear in human newborns.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the labour room with lower abdominal pain. Her vitals are BP - 90/60 mmHg and PR - 120 bpm. Fetal distress was noted and she was taken up for a caesarean section. The uterus appears as shown below.  Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is seen in revealed abruptio placenta
It is an indication for hysterectomy
It is a case of uteroplacental apoplexy

questions.solution:
The given image shows a couvelaire uterus or uteroplacental apoplexy which is seen in severe forms of concealed abruptio placenta. 

There is massive extravasation of blood into the uterine musculature up to the serosa. Thus, the uterus has a port wine colour, which can be patchy or diffuse. They can also extend to the broad ligament, ovaries and peritoneal cavity.

It is usually observed during caesarean section. It is not an indication of hysterectomy.

questions.text: The ENT resident uses the following system to classify the maxillary carcinoma. The 2 horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the below image are known as _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lederman’s classification and the two horizontal lines shown as "A" and "B" in the above image are called as Sebileau lines, one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through the floors of antrum.

 Sebileau lines divides the area into:

  • Suprastructure: It contains ethmoid, sphenoid, and frontal sinuses and the olfactory area of the nose.
  • Mesostructure: It has a maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
  • Infrastructure: It contains the alveolar process.

This classification further uses vertical lines, extending down the medial walls of orbit to separate ethmoidal sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses.

Other options:

  • Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through medial canthus of eye and angle of mandible
  • Lefort's lines are used for the classification of maxillary fractures

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for premature cataracts, thinning of skin, alopecia, osteoporosis, and atherosclerosis. She is found to have a hereditary genetic mutation in the WRN gene. This gene encodes which of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Werner syndrome, a premature aging disorder. The mutated gene encodes a DNA helicase. 

Werner syndrome is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the WRN gene. This gene encodes a protein with multiple DNA-dependent enzymatic functions including:

  • ATPase
  • Helicase
  • Exonuclease

DNA helicase is involved in DNA replication and repair. A defect in this enzyme causes rapid accumulation of damaged chromosomes that may mimic the injury that normally accumulates during cellular aging. Affected persons show various manifestations of premature aging including:  

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Senile cataract
  • Skin atrophy
  • Alopecia
  • Osteoporosis

They are also at risk for the development of a variety of cancers. Patients typically die in the 5th decade from either cancer or cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presented with painful swelling below the knee joint. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a traction injury of the tibial tuberosity, at the site where the patellar tendon is inserted, which is characteristic of Osgood-Schlatter Disease, also known as apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity.

The condition is usually seen in young adolescents and may not be associated with any injury.

The presenting feature is a painful lump below the knee joint. On examination, the lump is tender and its situation over the tibial tuberosity is diagnostic of the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Jumper’s knee, also known as patellar tendinitis is an inflammation of the proximal patellar tendon, which occurs due to overuse injury and is usually seen in athletes.

Option c: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome is seen where there is a partial rupture or avulsion of the distal patellar tendon, where it inserts into the patella, leading to traction tendonitis and calcification in the patellar ligament.

Option d: Osteochondritis Dissecans is a condition characterized by demarcation or separation and necrosis of a part of articular cartilage and bone. The condition is often associated with intra-articular loose bodies.

questions.text: What type of joint is formed between the structures marked as A and B?
questions.solution:
The structures marked A and B are the thyroid and cricoid cartilages, respectively. They articulate and form the cricothyroid joint which is a synovial joint.

The inferior horns of the thyroid cartilage and the cricoid cartilage form the cricothyroid joint. It is surrounded by a capsule and is reinforced by associated ligaments. The primary movement of the joint is rotation around a transverse axis that passes transversely through both cricothyroid joints. The effect of this movement is to effectively lengthen the vocal folds.  

Other options:

Option B: Bones in fibrous joints are joined by fibrous connective tissue. Three subtypes are sutures, gom­phoses, and syndesmoses, which allow a little movement. 

Option C: Primary cartilaginous joints also known as synchondroses are almost exclusively associated with growth plates.

Option D: Secondary cartilaginous joints also known as symphyses are present in manubriosternal, pubic symphysis, and intervertebral joints.

Related Pearl: Muscles of larynx

Remember 2 exceptions:

  • All muscles are adductors, except PCA (an abductor)
  • All muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except cricothyroid (superior laryngeal nerve)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman who is a chronic smoker had recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. The condition she is suffering from is________.
questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Other options: 

Option A: Tietze’s Syndrome is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

Option D: Paget's disease of the nipple is a superficial manifestation of underlying breast carcinoma. It presents as an eczema-like condition of the nipple
